Intercalated amygdaloid nuclei.EditorialNote: The intercalated amygdaloid nuclei may be better characterized as a cell group (NIF class) rather than a nucleus, because we describe them in terms of groupings of individual cells rather than masses of gray matter.
Intercalated amygdaloid nuclei.Definition: Discrete clusters of cells intercalated among the major amygdaloid nuclei.  They stain darkly in Nissl stains and have been identified in all mammals.  The main groups lie between the lateral-basolateral nuclear coplex and the central and medial nuclei.  Additional cell groups have been described by some in other locations (Millhouse, O. E. The intercalated cells of the amygdala. J Comp Neurol 247: 246-271, 1986).,  Groups of cells located between the lateral basolateral amygaloid nuclear complex and the central nucleus of the amygdala.  They stain darkly in Nissl stains and have been identified in all mammals.  (Millhouse, O. E. The intercalated cells of the amygdala. J Comp Neurol 247: 246-271, 1986)
